verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:1
verses.text: Against Hermogenes: The Opinions of Hermogenes, by the Prescriptive Rule of Antiquity Shown to Be Heretical.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:2
verses.text: Not Derived from Christianity, But from Heathen Philosophy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:3
verses.text: Some of the Tenets Mentioned.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:4
verses.text: We are accustomed, for the purpose of shortening argument, to lay down the rule against heretics of the lateness of their date.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:5
verses.text: For in as far as by our rule, priority is given to the truth, which also foretold that there would be heresies, in so far must all later opinions be prejudged as heresies, being such as were, by the more ancient rule of truth, predicted as (one day) to happen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:6
verses.text: Now, the doctrine of Hermogenes has this taint of novelty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:7
verses.text: He is, in short, a man living in the world at the present time; by his very nature a heretic, and turbulent withal, who mistakes loquacity for eloquence, and supposes impudence to be firmness, and judges it to be the duty of a good conscience to speak ill of individuals.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:8
verses.text: Moreover, he despises God's law in his painting, maintaining repeated marriages, alleges the law of God in defence of lust, and yet despises it in respect of his art.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:9
verses.text: He falsifies by a twofold process—with his cautery and his pen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:10
verses.text: He is a thorough adulterer, both doctrinally and carnally, since he is rank indeed with the contagion of your marriage-hacks, and has also failed in cleaving to the rule of faith as much as the apostle's own Hermogenes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:11
verses.text: However, never mind the man, when it is his doctrine which I question.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:12
verses.text: He does not appear to acknowledge any other Christ as Lord, though he holds Him in a different way; but by this difference in his faith he really makes Him another being,—nay, he takes from Him everything which is God, since he will not have it that He made all things of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 1:13
verses.text: For, turning away from Christians to the philosophers, from the Church to the Academy and the Porch, he learned there from the Stoics how to place Matter (on the same level) with the Lord, just as if it too had existed ever both unborn and unmade, having no beginning at all nor end, out of which, according to him, the Lord afterwards created all things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:1
verses.text: Hermogenes, After a Perverse Induction from Mere Heretical Assumptions, Concludes that God Created All Things Out of Pre-Existing Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:2
verses.text: Our very bad painter has coloured this his primary shade absolutely without any light, with such arguments as these: He begins with laying down the premiss, that the Lord made all things either out of Himself, or out of nothing, or out of something; in order that, after he has shown that it was impossible for Him to have made them either out of Himself or out of nothing, he might thence affirm the residuary proposition that He made them out of something, and therefore that that something was Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:3
verses.text: He could not have made all things, he says, of Himself; because whatever things the Lord made of Himself would have been parts of Himself; but He is not dissoluble into parts, because, being the Lord, He is indivisible, and unchangeable, and always the same.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:4
verses.text: Besides, if He had made anything out of Himself, it would have been something of Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:5
verses.text: Everything, however, both which was made and which He made must be accounted imperfect, because it was made of a part, and He made it of a part; or if, again, it was a whole which He made, who is a whole Himself, He must in that case have been at once both a whole, and yet not a whole; because it behoved Him to be a whole, that He might produce Himself, and yet not a whole, that He might be produced out of Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:6
verses.text: But this is a most difficult position.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:7
verses.text: For if He were in existence, He could not be made, for He was in existence already; if, however, he were not in existence He could not make, because He was a nonentity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:8
verses.text: He maintains, moreover, that He who always exists, does not come into existence, but exists for ever and ever.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:9
verses.text: He accordingly concludes that He made nothing out of Himself, since He never passed into such a condition as made it possible for Him to make anything out of Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:10
verses.text: In like manner, he contends that He could not have made all things out of nothing—thus:  He defines the Lord as a being who is good, nay, very good, who must will to make things as good and excellent as He is Himself; indeed it were impossible for Him either to will or to make anything which was not good, nay, very good itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:11
verses.text: Therefore all things ought to have been made good and excellent by Him, after His own condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:12
verses.text: Experience shows, however, that things which are even evil were made by Him: not, of course, of His own will and pleasure; because, if it had been of His own will and pleasure, He would be sure to have made nothing unfitting or unworthy of Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 2:13
verses.text: That, therefore, which He made not of His own will must be understood to have been made from the fault of something, and that is from Matter, without a doubt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:1
verses.text: An Argument of Hermogenes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:2
verses.text: The Answer:  While God is a Title Eternally Applicable to the Divine Being, Lord and Father are Only Relative Appellations, Not Eternally Applicable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:3
verses.text: An Inconsistency in the Argument of Hermogenes Pointed Out.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:4
verses.text: He adds also another point: that as God was always God, there was never a time when God was not also Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:5
verses.text: But it was in no way possible for Him to be regarded as always Lord, in the same manner as He had been always God, if there had not been always, in the previous eternity, a something of which He could be regarded as evermore the Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:6
verses.text: So he concludes that God always had Matter co-existent with Himself as the Lord thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:7
verses.text: Now, this tissue of his I shall at once hasten to pull abroad.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:8
verses.text: I have been willing to set it out in form to this length, for the information of those who are unacquainted with the subject, that they may know that his other arguments likewise need only be understood to be refuted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:9
verses.text: We affirm, then, that the name of God always existed with Himself and in Himself—but not eternally so the Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:10
verses.text: Because the condition of the one is not the same as that of the other.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:11
verses.text: God is the designation of the substance itself, that is, of the Divinity; but Lord is (the name) not of substance, but of power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:12
verses.text: I maintain that the substance existed always with its own name, which is God; the title Lord was afterwards added, as the indication indeed of something accruing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:13
verses.text: For from the moment when those things began to exist, over which the power of a Lord was to act, God, by the accession of that power, both became Lord and received the name thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:14
verses.text: Because God is in like manner a Father, and He is also a Judge; but He has not always been Father and Judge, merely on the ground of His having always been God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:15
verses.text: For He could not have been the Father previous to the Son, nor a Judge previous to sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:16
verses.text: There was, however, a time when neither sin existed with Him, nor the Son; the former of which was to constitute the Lord a Judge, and the latter a Father.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:17
verses.text: In this way He was not Lord previous to those things of which He was to be the Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:18
verses.text: But He was only to become Lord at some future time: just as He became the Father by the Son, and a Judge by sin, so also did He become Lord by means of those things which He had made, in order that they might serve Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:19
verses.text: Do I seem to you to be weaving arguments, Hermogenes? How neatly does Scripture lend us its aid, when it applies the two titles to Him with a distinction, and reveals them each at its proper time! For (the title) God, indeed, which always belonged to Him, it names at the very first: "In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth;" and as long as He continued making, one after the other, those things of which He was to be the Lord, it merely mentions God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:20
verses.text: "And God said," "and God made," "and God saw;" but nowhere do we yet find the Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:21
verses.text: But when He completed the whole creation, and especially man himself, who was destined to understand His sovereignty in a way of special propriety, He then is designated Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:22
verses.text: Then also the Scripture added the name Lord: "And the Lord God, Deus Dominus, took the man, whom He had formed;" "And the Lord God commanded Adam".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:23
verses.text: Thenceforth He, who was previously God only, is the Lord, from the time of His having something of which He might be the Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:24
verses.text: For to Himself He was always God, but to all things was He only then God, when He became also Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:25
verses.text: Therefore, in as far as (Hermogenes) shall suppose that Matter was eternal, on the ground that the Lord was eternal, in so far will it be evident that nothing existed, because it is plain that the Lord as such did not always exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:26
verses.text: Now I mean also, on my own part, to add a remark for the sake of ignorant persons, of whom Hermogenes is an extreme instance, and actually to retort against him his own arguments.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:27
verses.text: For when he denies that Matter was born or made, I find that, even on these terms, the title Lord is unsuitable to God in respect of Matter, because it must have been free, when by not having a beginning it had not an author.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:28
verses.text: The fact of its past existence it owed to no one, so that it could be a subject to no one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 3:29
verses.text: Therefore ever since God exercised His power over it, by creating (all things) out of Matter, although it had all along experienced God as its Lord, yet Matter does, after all, demonstrate that God did not exist in the relation of Lord to it, although all the while He was really so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:1
verses.text: Hermogenes Gives Divine Attributes to Matter, and So Makes Two Gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:2
verses.text: At this point, then, I shall begin to treat of Matter, how that, (according to Hermogenes,) God compares it with Himself as equally unborn, equally unmade, equally eternal, set forth as being without a beginning, without an end.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:3
verses.text: For what other estimate of God is there than eternity? What other condition has eternity than to have ever existed, and to exist yet for evermore by virtue of its privilege of having neither beginning nor end? Now, since this is the property of God, it will belong to God alone, whose property it is—of course on this ground, that if it can be ascribed to any other being, it will no longer be the property of God, but will belong, along with Him, to that being also to which it is ascribed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:4
verses.text: For "although there be that are called gods" in name, "whether in heaven or in earth, yet to us there is but one God the Father, of whom are all things;" whence the greater reason why, in our view, that which is the property of God ought to be regarded as pertaining to God alone, and why (as I have already said) that should cease to be such a property, when it is shared by another being.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:5
verses.text: Now, since He is God, it must necessarily be a unique mark of this quality, that it be confined to One.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:6
verses.text: Else, what will be unique and singular, if that is not which has nothing equal to it? What will be principal, if that is not which is above all things, before all things, and from which all things proceed? By possessing these He is God alone, and by His sole possession of them He is One.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:7
verses.text: If another also shared in the possession, there would then be as many gods as there were possessors of these attributes of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:8
verses.text: Hermogenes, therefore, introduces two gods: he introduces Matter as God's equal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 4:9
verses.text: God, however, must be One, because that is God which is supreme; but nothing else can be supreme than that which is unique; and that cannot possibly be unique which has anything equal to it; and Matter will be equal with God when it is held to be eternal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:1
verses.text: Hermogenes Coquets with His Own Argument, as If Rather Afraid of It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:2
verses.text: After Investing Matter with Divine Qualities, He Tries to Make It Somehow Inferior to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:3
verses.text: But God is God, and Matter is Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:4
verses.text: As if a mere difference in their names prevented equality, when an identity of condition is claimed for them! Grant that their nature is different; assume, too, that their form is not identical,—what matters it so long as their absolute state have but one mode? God is unborn; is not Matter also unborn? God ever exists; is not Matter, too, ever existent? Both are without beginning; both are without end; both are the authors of the universe—both He who created it, and the Matter of which He made it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:5
verses.text: For it is impossible that Matter should not be regarded as the author of all things, when the universe is composed of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:6
verses.text: What answer will he give? Will he say that Matter is not then comparable with God as soon as it has something belonging to God; since, by not having total (divinity), it cannot correspond to the whole extent of the comparison? But what more has he reserved for God, that he should not seem to have accorded to Matter the full amount of the Deity? He says in reply, that even though this is the prerogative of Matter, both the authority and the substance of God must remain intact, by virtue of which He is regarded as the sole and prime Author, as well as the Lord of all things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:7
verses.text: Truth, however, maintains the unity of God in such a way as to insist that whatever belongs to God Himself belongs to Him alone.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:8
verses.text: For so will it belong to Himself if it belong to Him alone; and therefore it will be impossible that another god should be admitted, when it is permitted to no other being to possess anything of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:9
verses.text: Well, then, you say, we ourselves at that rate possess nothing of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:10
verses.text: But indeed we do, and shall continue to do—only it is from Him that we receive it, and not from ourselves.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:11
verses.text: For we shall be even gods, if we, shall deserve to be among those of whom He declared, "I have said, Ye are gods," and, "God standeth in the congregation of the gods".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:12
verses.text: But this comes of His own grace, not from any property in us, because it is He alone who can make gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:13
verses.text: The property of Matter, however, he makes to be that which it has in common with God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:14
verses.text: Otherwise, if it received from God the property which belongs to God,—I mean its attribute of eternity—one might then even suppose that it both possesses an attribute in common with God, and yet at the same time is not God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 5:15
verses.text: But what inconsistency is it for him to allow that there is a conjoint possession of an attribute with God, and also to wish that what he does not refuse to Matter should be, after all, the exclusive privilege of God!.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:1
verses.text: The Shifts to Which Hermogenes is Reduced, Who Deifies Matter, and Yet is Unwilling to Hold Him Equal with the Divine Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:2
verses.text: He declares that God's attribute is still safe to Him, of being the only God, and the First, and the Author of all things, and the Lord of all things, and being incomparable to any—qualities which he straightway ascribes to Matter also.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:3
verses.text: He is God, to be sure.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:4
verses.text: God shall also attest the same; but He has also sworn sometimes by Himself, that there is no other God like Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:5
verses.text: Hermogenes, however, will make Him a liar.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:6
verses.text: For Matter will be such a God as He—being unmade, unborn, without beginning, and without end.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:7
verses.text: God will say, "I am the first!" Yet how is He the first, when Matter is co-eternal with Him? Between co-eternals and contemporaries there is no sequence of rank.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:8
verses.text: Is then, Matter also the first? "I," says the Lord, "have stretched out the heavens alone".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:9
verses.text: But indeed He was not alone, when that likewise stretched them out, of which He made the expanse.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:10
verses.text: When he asserts the position that Matter was eternal, without any encroachment on the condition of God, let him see to it that we do not in ridicule turn the tables on him, that God similarly was eternal without any encroachment on the condition of Matter—the condition of Both being still common to Them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:11
verses.text: The position, therefore, remains unimpugned both in the case of Matter, that it did itself exist, only along with God; and that God existed alone, but with Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:12
verses.text: It also was first with God, as God, too, was first with it; it, however, is not comparable with God, as God, too, is not to be compared with it; with God also it was the Author (of all things), and with God their Sovereign.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:13
verses.text: In this way he proposes that God has something, and yet not the whole, of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:14
verses.text: For Him, accordingly, Hermogenes has reserved nothing which he had not equally conferred on Matter, so that it is not Matter which is compared with God, but rather God who is compared with Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 6:15
verses.text: Now, inasmuch as those qualities which we claim as peculiar to God—to have always existed, without a beginning, without an end, and to have been the First, and Alone, and the Author of all things—are also compatible to Matter, I want to know what property Matter possesses different and alien from God, and hereby special to itself, by reason of which it is incapable of being compared with God? That Being, in which occur all the properties of God, is sufficiently predetermined without any further comparison.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:1
verses.text: Hermogenes Held to His Theory in Order that Its Absurdity May Be Exposed on His Own Principles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:2
verses.text: When he contends that matter is less than God, and inferior to Him, and therefore diverse from Him, and for the same reason not a fit subject of comparison with Him, who is a greater and superior Being, I meet him with this prescription, that what is eternal and unborn is incapable of any diminution and inferiority, because it is simply this which makes even God to be as great as He is, inferior and subject to none—nay, greater and higher than all.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:3
verses.text: For, just as all things which are born, or which come to an end, and are therefore not eternal, do, by reason of their exposure at once to an end and a beginning, admit of qualities which are repugnant to God—I mean diminution and inferiority, because they are born and made—so likewise God, for this very reason, is unsusceptible of these accidents, because He is absolutely unborn, and also unmade.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:4
verses.text: And yet such also is the condition of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:5
verses.text: Therefore, of the two Beings which are eternal, as being unborn and unmade—God and Matter—by reason of the identical mode of their common condition (both of them equally possessing that which admits neither of diminution nor subjection—that is, the attribute of eternity), we affirm that neither of them is less or greater than the other, neither of them is inferior or superior to the other; but that they both stand on a par in greatness, on a par in sublimity, and on the same level of that complete and perfect felicity of which eternity is reckoned to consist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:6
verses.text: Now we must not resemble the heathen in our opinions; for they, when constrained to acknowledge God, insist on having other deities below Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:7
verses.text: The Divinity, however, has no degrees, because it is unique; and if it shall be found in Matter—as being equally unborn and unmade and eternal—it must be resident in both alike, because in no case can it be inferior to itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:8
verses.text: In what way, then, will Hermogenes have the courage to draw distinctions; and thus to subject matter to God, an eternal to the Eternal, an unborn to the Unborn, an author to the Author? seeing that it dares to say, I also am the first; I too am before all things; and I am that from which all things proceed; equal we have been, together we have been—both alike without beginning, without end; both alike without an Author, without a God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:9
verses.text: What God, then, is He who subjects me to a contemporaneous, co-eternal power? If it be He who is called God, then I myself, too, have my own (divine) name.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:10
verses.text: Either I am God, or He is Matter, because we both are that which neither of us is.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 7:11
verses.text: Do you suppose, therefore, that he has not made Matter equal with God, although, forsooth, he pretends it to be inferior to Him?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:1
verses.text: On His Own Principles, Hermogenes Makes Matter, on the Whole, Superior to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:2
verses.text: Nay more, he even prefers Matter to God, and rather subjects God to it, when he will have it that God made all things out of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:3
verses.text: For if He drew His resources from it for the creation of the world, Matter is already found to be the superior, inasmuch as it furnished Him with the means of effecting His works; and God is thereby clearly subjected to Matter, of which the substance was indispensable to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:4
verses.text: For there is no one but requires that which he makes use of; no one but is subject to the thing which he requires, for the very purpose of being able to make use of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:5
verses.text: So, again, there is no one who, from using what belongs to another, is not inferior to him of whose property he makes use; and there is no one who imparts of his own for another's use, who is not in this respect superior to him to whose use he lends his property.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:6
verses.text: On this principle, Matter itself, no doubt, was not in want of God, but rather lent itself to God, who was in want of it—rich and abundant and liberal as it was—to one who was, I suppose, too small, and too weak, and too unskilful, to form what He willed out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:7
verses.text: A grand service, verily, did it confer on God in giving Him means at the present time whereby He might be known to be God, and be called Almighty—only that He is no longer Almighty, since He is not powerful enough for this, to produce all things out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:8
verses.text: To be sure, Matter bestowed somewhat on itself also—even to get its own self acknowledged with God as God's co-equal, nay more, as His helper; only there is this drawback, that Hermogenes is the only man that has found out this fact, besides the philosophers—those patriarchs of all heresy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 8:9
verses.text: For the prophets knew nothing about it, nor the apostles thus far, nor, I suppose, even Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:1
verses.text: Sundry Inevitable But Intolerable Conclusions from the Principles of Hermogenes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:2
verses.text: He cannot say that it was as its Lord that God employed Matter for His creative works, for He could not have been the Lord of a substance which was co-equal with Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:3
verses.text: Well, but perhaps it was a title derived from the will of another, which he enjoyed—a precarious holding, and not a lordship, and that to such a degree, that although Matter was evil, He yet endured to make use of an evil substance, owing, of course, to the restraint of His own limited power, which made Him impotent to create out of nothing, not in consequence of His power; for if, as God, He had at all possessed power over Matter which He knew to be evil, He would first have converted it into good—as its Lord and the good God—that so He might have a good thing to make use of, instead of a bad one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:4
verses.text: But being undoubtedly good, only not the Lord withal, He, by using such power as He possessed, showed the necessity He was under of yielding to the condition of Matter, which He would have amended if He had been its Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:5
verses.text: Now this is the answer which must be given to Hermogenes when he maintains that it was by virtue of His Lordship that God used Matter—even of His non-possession of any right to it, on the ground, of course, of His not having Himself made it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:6
verses.text: Evil then, on your terms, must proceed from God Himself, since He is—I will not say the Author of evil, because He did not form it, but—the permitter thereof, as having dominion over it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:7
verses.text: If indeed Matter shall prove not even to belong to God at all, as being evil, it follows, that when He made use of what belonged to another, He used it either on a precarious title because He was in need of it, or else by violent possession because He was stronger than it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:8
verses.text: For by three methods is the property of others obtained,—by right, by permission, by violence; in other words, by lordship, by a title derived from the will of another, by force.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:9
verses.text: Now, as lordship is out of the question, Hermogenes must choose which (of the other methods) is suitable to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 9:10
verses.text: Did He, then, make all things out of Matter, by permission, or by force?  But, in truth, would not God have more wisely determined that nothing at all should be created, than that it should be created by the mere sufferance of another, or by violence, and that, too, with a substance which was evil?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:1
verses.text: To What Straits Hermogenes Absurdly Reduces the Divine Being.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:2
verses.text: He Does Nothing Short of Making Him the Author of Evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:3
verses.text: Even if Matter had been the perfection of good, would it not have been equally indecorous in Him to have thought of the property of another, however good, (to effect His purpose by the help of it)? It was, therefore, absurd enough for Him, in the interest of His own glory, to have created the world in such a way as to betray His own obligation to a substance which belonged to another—and that even not good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:4
verses.text: Was He then, asks (Hermogenes), to make all things out of nothing, that so evil things themselves might be attributed to His will?  Great, in all conscience, must be the blindness of our heretics which leaves them to argue in such a way that they either insist on the belief of another God supremely good, on the ground of their thinking the Creator to be the author of evil, or else they set up Matter with the Creator, in order that they may derive evil from Matter, not from the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:5
verses.text: And yet there is absolutely no god at all that is free from such a doubtful plight, so as to be able to avoid the appearance even of being the author of evil, whosoever he is that—I will not say, indeed, has made, but still—has permitted evil to be made by some author or other, and from some source or other.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:6
verses.text: Hermogenes, therefore, ought to be told at once, although we postpone to another place our distinction concerning the mode of evil, that even he has effected no result by this device of his.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:7
verses.text: For observe how God is found to be, if not the Author of, yet at any rate the conniver at, evil, inasmuch as He, with all His extreme goodness, endured evil in Matter before He created the world, although, as being good, and the enemy of evil, He ought to have corrected it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:8
verses.text: For He either was able to correct it, but was unwilling; or else was willing, but being a weak God, was not able.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:9
verses.text: If He was able and yet unwilling, He was Himself evil, as having favoured evil; and thus He now opens Himself to the charge of evil, because even if He did not create it yet still, since it would not be existing if He had been against its existence, He must Himself have then caused it to exist, when He refused to will its non-existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:10
verses.text: And what is more shameful than this? When He willed that to be which He was Himself unwilling to create, He acted in fact against His very self, inasmuch as He was both willing that that should exist which He was unwilling to make, and unwilling to make that which He was willing should exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:11
verses.text: As if what He willed was good, and at the same time what he refused to be the Maker of was evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:12
verses.text: What He judged to be evil by not creating it, He also proclaimed to be good by permitting it to exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:13
verses.text: By bearing with evil as a good instead of rather extirpating it, He proved Himself to be the promoter thereof; criminally, if through His own will—disgracefully, if through necessity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 10:14
verses.text: God must either be the servant of evil or the friend thereof, since He held converse with evil in Matter—nay, more, effected His works out of the evil thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:1
verses.text: Hermogenes Makes Great Efforts to Remove Evil from God to Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:2
verses.text: How He Fails to Do This Consistently with His Own Argument.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:3
verses.text: But, after all, by what proofs does Hermogenes persuade us that Matter is evil? For it will be impossible for him not to call that evil to which he imputes evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:4
verses.text: Now we lay down this principle, that what is eternal cannot possibly admit of diminution and subjection, so as to be considered inferior to another co-eternal Being.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:5
verses.text: So that we now affirm that evil is not even compatible with it, since it is incapable of subjection, from the fact that it cannot in any wise be subject to any, because it is eternal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:6
verses.text: But inasmuch as, on other grounds, it is evident what is eternal as God is the highest good, whereby also He alone is good—as being eternal, and therefore good—as being God, how can evil be inherent in Matter, which (since it is eternal) must needs be believed to be the highest good? Else if that which is eternal prove to be also capable of evil, this (evil) will be able to be also believed of God to His prejudice; so that it is without adequate reason that he has been so anxious to remove evil from God; since evil must be compatible with an eternal Being, even by being made compatible with Matter, as Hermogenes makes it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:7
verses.text: But, as the argument now stands, since what is eternal can be deemed evil, the evil must prove to be invincible and insuperable, as being eternal; and in that case it will be in vain that we labour "to put away evil from the midst of us;" in that case, moreover, God vainly gives us such a command and precept; nay more, in vain has God appointed any judgment at all, when He means, indeed, to inflict punishment with injustice.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:8
verses.text: But if, on the other hand, there is to be an end of evil, when the chief thereof, the devil, shall "go away into the fire which God hath prepared for him and his angels"—having been first "cast into the bottomless pit;" when likewise "the manifestation of the children of God" shall have "delivered the creature" from evil, which had been "made subject to vanity;" when the cattle restored in the innocence and integrity of their nature shall be at peace with the beasts of the field, when also little children shall play with serpents; when the Father shall have put beneath the feet of His Son His enemies, as being the workers of evil,—if in this way an end is compatible with evil, it must follow of necessity that a beginning is also compatible with it; and Matter will turn out to have a beginning, by virtue of its having also an end.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 11:9
verses.text: For whatever things are set to the account of evil, have a compatibility with the condition of evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:1
verses.text: The Mode of Controversy Changed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:2
verses.text: The Premisses of Hermogenes Accepted, in Order to Show into What Confusion They Lead Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:3
verses.text: Come now, let us suppose Matter to be evil, nay, very evil, by nature of course, just as we believe God to be good, even very good, in like manner by nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:4
verses.text: Now nature must be regarded as sure and fixed, just as persistently fixed in evil in the case of Matter, as immoveable and unchangeable in good in the case of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:5
verses.text: Because, as is evident, if nature admits of change from evil to good in Matter, it can be changed from good to evil in God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:6
verses.text: Here some man will say, Then will "children not be raised up to Abraham from the stones?" Will "generations of vipers not bring forth the fruit of repentance?" And "children of wrath" fail to become sons of peace, if nature be unchangeable?  Your reference to such examples as these, my friend, is a thoughtless one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:7
verses.text: For things which owe their existence to birth such as stones and vipers and human beings—are not apposite to the case of Matter, which is unborn; since their nature, by possessing a beginning, may have also a termination.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:8
verses.text: But bear in mind that Matter has once for all been determined to be eternal, as being unmade, unborn, and therefore supposably of an unchangeable and incorruptible nature; and this from the very opinion of Hermogenes himself, which he alleges against us when he denies that God was able to make (anything) of Himself, on the ground that what is eternal is incapable of change, because it would lose—so the opinion runs—what it once was, in becoming by the change that which it was not, if it were not eternal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:9
verses.text: But as for the Lord, who is also eternal, (he maintained) that He could not be anything else than what He always is.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:10
verses.text: Well, then, I will adopt this definite opinion of his, and by means thereof refute him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:11
verses.text: I blame Matter with a like censure, because out of it, evil though it be—nay, very evil—good things have been created, nay, "very good" ones: "And God saw that they were good, and God blessed them"—because, of course, of their very great goodness; certainly not because they were evil, or very evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:12
verses.text: Change is therefore admissible in Matter; and this being the case, it has lost its condition of eternity; in short, its beauty is decayed in death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:13
verses.text: Eternity, however, cannot be lost, because it cannot be eternity, except by reason of its immunity from loss.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 12:14
verses.text: For the same reason also it is incapable of change, inasmuch as, since it is eternity, it can by no means be changed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 13:1
verses.text: Another Ground of Hermogenes that Matter Has Some Good in It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 13:2
verses.text: Its Absurdity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 13:3
verses.text: Here the question will arise How creatures were made good out of it, which were formed without any change at all? How occurs the seed of what is good, nay, very good, in that which is evil, nay, very evil? Surely a good tree does not produce evil fruit, since there is no God who is not good; nor does an evil tree yield good fruit, since there is not Matter except what is very evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 13:4
verses.text: Or if we were to grant him that there is some germ of good in it, then there will be no longer a uniform nature (pervading it), that is to say, one which is evil throughout; but instead thereof (we now encounter) a double nature, partly good and partly evil; and again the question will arise, whether, in a subject which is good and evil, there could possibly have been found a harmony for light and darkness, for sweet and bitter? So again, if qualities so utterly diverse as good and evil have been able to unite together, and have imparted to Matter a double nature, productive of both kinds of fruit, then no longer will absolutely good things be imputable to God, just as evil things are not ascribed to Him, but both qualities will appertain to Matter, since they are derived from the property of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 13:5
verses.text: At this rate, we shall owe to God neither gratitude for good things, nor grudge for evil ones, because He has produced no work of His own proper character.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 13:6
verses.text: From which circumstance will arise the clear proof that He has been subservient to Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:1
verses.text: Tertullian Pushes His Opponent into a Dilemma.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:2
verses.text: Now, if it be also argued, that although Matter may have afforded Him the opportunity, it was still His own will which led Him to the creation of good creatures, as having detected what was good in matter—although this, too, be a discreditable supposition—yet, at any rate, when He produces evil likewise out of the same (Matter), He is a servant to Matter, since, of course, it is not of His own accord that He produces this too, having nothing else that He can do than to effect creation out of an evil stock—unwillingly, no doubt, as being good; of necessity, too, as being unwilling; and as an act of servitude, because from necessity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:3
verses.text: Which, then, is the worthier thought, that He created evil things of necessity, or of His own accord? Because it was indeed of necessity that He created them, if out of Matter; of His own accord, if out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:4
verses.text: For you are now labouring in vain when you try to avoid making God the Author of evil things; because, since He made all things of Matter, they will have to be ascribed to Himself, who made them, just because He made them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:5
verses.text: Plainly the interest of the question, whence He made all things, identifies itself with (the question), whether He made all things out of nothing; and it matters not whence He made all things, so that He made all things thence, whence most glory accrued to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:6
verses.text: Now, more glory accrued to Him from a creation of His own will than from one of necessity; in other words, from a creation out of nothing, than from one out of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:7
verses.text: It is more worthy to believe that God is free, even as the Author of evil, than that He is a slave.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:8
verses.text: Power, whatever it be, is more suited to Him than infirmity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:9
verses.text: If we thus even admit that matter had nothing good in it, but that the Lord produced whatever good He did produce of His own power, then some other questions will with equal reason arise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:10
verses.text: First, since there was no good at all in Matter, it is clear that good was not made of Matter, on the express ground indeed that Matter did not possess it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:11
verses.text: Next, if good was not made of Matter, it must then have been made of God; if not of God, then it must have been made of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 14:12
verses.text: —For this is the alternative, on Hermogenes' own showing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:1
verses.text: The Truth, that God Made All Things from Nothing, Rescued from the Opponent's Flounderings.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:2
verses.text: Now, if good was neither produced out of matter, since it was not in it, evil as it was, nor out of God, since, according to the position of Hermogenes, nothing could have been produced out of god, it will be found that good was created out of nothing, inasmuch as it was formed of none—neither of Matter nor of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:3
verses.text: And if good was formed out of nothing, why not evil too? Nay, if anything was formed out of nothing, why not all things?  Unless indeed it be that the divine might was insufficient for the production of all things, though it produced a something out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:4
verses.text: Or else if good proceeded from evil matter, since it issued neither from nothing nor from God, it will follow that it must have proceeded from the conversion of Matter contrary to that unchangeable attribute which has been claimed for it, as an eternal being.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:5
verses.text: Thus, in regard to the source whence good derived its existence, Hermogenes will now have to deny the possibility of such.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:6
verses.text: But still it is necessary that (good) should proceed from some one of those sources from which he has denied the very possibility of its having been derived.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:7
verses.text: Now if evil be denied to be of nothing for the purpose of denying it to be the work of God, from whose will there would be too much appearance of its being derived, and be alleged to proceed from Matter, that it may be the property of that very thing of whose substance it is assumed to be made, even here also, as I have said, God will have to be regarded as the Author of evil; because, whereas it had been His duty to produce all good things out of Matter, or rather good things simply, by His identical attribute of power and will, He did yet not only not produce all good things, but even (some) evil things—of course, either willing that the evil should exist if He was able to cause their non-existence, or not being strong enough to effect that all things should be good, if being desirous of that result, He failed in the accomplishment thereof; since there can be no difference whether it were by weakness or by will, that the Lord proved to be the Author of evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:8
verses.text: Else what was the reason that, after creating good things, as if Himself good, He should have also produced evil things, as if He failed in His goodness, since He did not confine Himself to the production of things which were simply consistent with Himself? What necessity was there, after the production of His proper work, for His troubling Himself about Matter also by producing evil likewise, in order to secure His being alone acknowledged as good from His good, and at the same time to prevent Matter being regarded as evil from (created) evil? Good would have flourished much better if evil had not blown upon it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:9
verses.text: For Hermogenes himself explodes the arguments of sundry persons who contend that evil things were necessary to impart lustre to the good, which must be understood from their contrasts.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 15:10
verses.text: This, therefore, was not the ground for the production of evil; but if some other reason must be sought for the introduction thereof, why could it not have been introduced even from nothing, since the very same reason would exculpate the Lord from the reproach of being thought the author of evil, which now excuses the existence of evil things, when He produces them out of Matter? And if there is this excuse, then the question is completely shut up in a corner, where they are unwilling to find it, who, without examining into the reason itself of evil, or distinguishing how they should either attribute it to God or separate it from God, do in fact expose God to many most unworthy calumnies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:1
verses.text: A Series of Dilemmas.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:2
verses.text: They Show that Hermogenes Cannot Escape from the Orthodox Conclusion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:3
verses.text: On the very threshold, then, of this doctrine, which I shall probably have to treat of elsewhere, I distinctly lay it down as my position, that both good and evil must be ascribed either to God, who made them out of Matter; or to Matter itself, out of which He made them; or both one and the other to both of them together, because they are bound together—both He who created, and that out of which He created; or (lastly) one to One and the other to the Other, because after Matter and God there is not a third.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:4
verses.text: Now if both should prove to belong to God, God evidently will be the author of evil; but God, as being good, cannot be the author of evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:5
verses.text: Again, if both are ascribed to Matter, Matter will evidently be the very mother of good, but inasmuch as Matter is wholly evil, it cannot be the mother of good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:6
verses.text: But if both one and the other should be thought to belong to Both together, then in this case also Matter will be comparable with God; and both will be equal, being on equal terms allied to evil as well as to good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:7
verses.text: Matter, however, ought not to be compared with God, in order that it may not make two gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:8
verses.text: If, (lastly,) one be ascribed to One, and the other to the Other—that is to say, let the good be God's, and the evil belong to Matter—then, on the one hand, evil must not be ascribed to God, nor, on the other hand, good to Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:9
verses.text: And God, moreover, by making both good things and evil things out of Matter, creates them along with it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:10
verses.text: This being the case, I cannot tell how Hermogenes is to escape from my conclusion; for he supposes that God cannot be the author of evil, in what way soever He created evil out of Matter, whether it was of His own will, or of necessity, or from the reason (of the case).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:11
verses.text: If, however, He is the author of evil, who was the actual Creator, Matter being simply associated with Him by reason of its furnishing Him with substance, you now do away with the cause of your introducing Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:12
verses.text: For it is not the less true, that it is by means of Matter that God shows Himself the author of evil, although Matter has been assumed by you expressly to prevent God's seeming to be the author of evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:13
verses.text: Matter being therefore excluded, since the cause of it is excluded, it remains that God without doubt, must have made all things out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:14
verses.text: Whether evil things were amongst them we shall see, when it shall be made clear what are evil things, and whether those things are evil which you at present deem to be so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:15
verses.text: For it is more worthy of God that He produced even these of His own will, by producing them out of nothing, than from the predetermination of another, (which must have been the case) if He had produced them out of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:16
verses.text: It is liberty, not necessity, which suits the character of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 16:17
verses.text: I would much rather that He should have even willed to create evil of Himself, than that He should have lacked ability to hinder its creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 17:1
verses.text: The Truth of God's Work in Creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 17:2
verses.text: You Cannot Depart in the Least from It, Without Landing Yourself in an Absurdity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 17:3
verses.text: This rule is required by the nature of the One-only God, who is One-only in no other way than as the sole God; and in no other way sole, than as having nothing else (co-existent) with Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 17:4
verses.text: So also He will be first, because all things are after Him; and all things are after Him, because all things are by Him; and all things are by Him, because they are of nothing: so that reason coincides with the Scripture, which says: "Who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath been His counsellor? or with whom took He counsel? or who hath shown to Him the way of wisdom and knowledge? Who hath first given to Him, and it shall be recompensed to him again?" Surely none!  Because there was present with Him no power, no material, no nature which belonged to any other than Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 17:5
verses.text: But if it was with some (portion of Matter) that He effected His creation, He must have received from that (Matter) itself both the design and the treatment of its order as being "the way of wisdom and knowledge".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 17:6
verses.text: For He had to operate conformably with the quality of the thing, and according to the nature of Matter, not according to His own will in consequence of which He must have made even evil things suitably to the nature not of Himself, but of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:1
verses.text: An Eulogy on the Wisdom and Word of God, by Which God Made All Things of Nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:2
verses.text: If any material was necessary to God in the creation of the world, as Hermogenes supposed, God had a far nobler and more suitable one in His own wisdom—one which was not to be gauged by the writings of philosophers, but to be learnt from the words or prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:3
verses.text: This alone, indeed, knew the mind of the Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:4
verses.text: For "who knoweth the things of God, and the things in God, but the Spirit, which is in Him?" Now His wisdom is that Spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:5
verses.text: This was His counsellor, the very way of His wisdom and knowledge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:6
verses.text: Of this He made all things, making them through It, and making them with It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:7
verses.text: "When He prepared the heavens," so says (the Scripture), "I was present with Him; and when He strengthened above the winds the lofty clouds, and when He secured the fountains which are under the heaven, I was present, compacting these things along with Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:8
verses.text: I was He in whom He took delight; moreover, I daily rejoiced in His presence: for He rejoiced when He had finished the world, and amongst the sons of men did He show forth His pleasure".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:9
verses.text: Now, who would not rather approve of this as the fountain and origin of all things—of this as, in very deed, the Matter of all Matter, not liable to any end, not diverse in condition, not restless in motion, not ungraceful in form, but natural, and proper, and duly proportioned, and beautiful, such truly as even God might well have required, who requires His own and not another's? Indeed, as soon as He perceived It to be necessary for His creation of the world, He immediately creates It, and generates It in Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:10
verses.text: "The Lord," says the Scripture, "possessed me, the beginning of His ways for the creation of His works.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:11
verses.text: Before the worlds He founded me; before He made the earth, before the mountains were settled in their places; moreover, before the hills He generated me, and prior to the depths was I begotten".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:12
verses.text: Let Hermogenes then confess that the very Wisdom of God is declared to be born and created, for the especial reason that we should not suppose that there is any other being than God alone who is unbegotten and uncreated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:13
verses.text: For if that, which from its being inherent in the Lord was of Him and in Him, was yet not without a beginning,—I mean His wisdom, which was then born and created, when in the thought of God It began to assume motion for the arrangement of His creative works,—how much more impossible is it that anything should have been without a beginning which was extrinsic to the Lord! But if this same Wisdom is the Word of God, in the capacity of Wisdom, and (as being He) without whom nothing was made, just as also (nothing) was set in order without Wisdom, how can it be that anything, except the Father, should be older, and on this account indeed nobler, than the Son of God, the only-begotten and first-begotten Word?  Not to say that what is unbegotten is stronger than that which is born, and what is not made more powerful than that which is made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:14
verses.text: Because that which did not require a Maker to give it existence, will be much more elevated in rank than that which had an author to bring it into being.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:15
verses.text: On this principle, then, if evil is indeed unbegotten, whilst the Son of God is begotten ("for," says God, "my heart hath emitted my most excellent Word"), I am not quite sure that evil may not be introduced by good, the stronger by the weak, in the same way as the unbegotten is by the begotten.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:16
verses.text: Therefore on this ground Hermogenes puts Matter even before God, by putting it before the Son.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:17
verses.text: Because the Son is the Word, and "the Word is God," and "I and my Father are one".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 18:18
verses.text: But after all, perhaps, the Son will patiently enough submit to having that preferred before Him which (by Hermogenes), is made equal to the Father!.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:1
verses.text: An Appeal to the History of Creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:2
verses.text: True Meaning of the Term Beginning, Which the Heretic Curiously Wrests to an Absurd Sense.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:3
verses.text: But I shall appeal to the original document of Moses, by help of which they on the other side vainly endeavour to prop up their conjectures, with the view, of course, of appearing to have the support of that authority which is indispensable in such an inquiry.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:4
verses.text: They have found their opportunity, as is usual with heretics, in wresting the plain meaning of certain words.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:5
verses.text: For instance the very beginning, when God made the heaven and the earth, they will construe as if it meant something substantial and embodied, to be regarded as Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:6
verses.text: We, however, insist on the proper signification of every word, and say that principium means beginning,—being a term which is suitable to represent things which begin to exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:7
verses.text: For nothing which has come into being is without a beginning, nor can this its commencement be at any other moment than when it begins to have existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:8
verses.text: Thus principium or beginning, is simply a term of inception, not the name of a substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:9
verses.text: Now, inasmuch as the heaven and the earth are the principal works of God, and since, by His making them first, He constituted them in an especial manner the beginning of His creation, before all things else, with good reason does the Scripture preface (its record of creation) with the words, "In the beginning God made the heaven and the earth;" just as it would have said, "At last God made the heaven and the earth," if God had created these after all the rest.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:10
verses.text: Now, if the beginning is a substance, the end must also be material.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:11
verses.text: No doubt, a substantial thing may be the beginning of some other thing which may be formed out of it; thus the clay is the beginning of the vessel, and the seed is the beginning of the plant.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:12
verses.text: But when we employ the word beginning in this sense of origin, and not in that of order, we do not omit to mention also the name of that particular thing which we regard as the origin of the other.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:13
verses.text: On the other hand, if we were to make such a statement as this, for example, "In the beginning the potter made a basin or a water-jug," the word beginning will not here indicate a material substance (for I have not mentioned the clay, which is the beginning in this sense, but only the order of the work, meaning that the potter made the basin and the jug first, before anything else—intending afterwards to make the rest.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:14
verses.text: It is, then, to the order of the works that the word beginning has reference, not to the origin of their substances.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:15
verses.text: I might also explain this word beginning in another way, which would not, however, be inapposite.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:16
verses.text: The Greek term for beginning, which is ἀρχή, admits the sense not only of priority of order, but of power as well; whence princes and magistrates are called ἀρχοντες.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:17
verses.text: Therefore in this sense too, beginning may be taken for princely authority and power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 19:18
verses.text: It was, indeed, in His transcendent authority and power, that God made the heaven and the earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:1
verses.text: Meaning of the Phrase—In the Beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:2
verses.text: Tertullian Connects It with the Wisdom of God, and Elicits from It the Truth that the Creation Was Not Out of Pre-Existent Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:3
verses.text: But in proof that the Greek word means nothing else than beginning, and that beginning admits of no other sense than the initial one, we have that (Being) even acknowledging such a beginning, who says:  "The Lord possessed me, the beginning of His ways for the creation of His works".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:4
verses.text: For since all things were made by the Wisdom of God, it follows that, when God made both the heaven and the earth in principio—that is to say, in the beginning—He made them in His Wisdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:5
verses.text: If, indeed, beginning had a material signification, the Scripture would not have informed us that God made so and so in principio, at the beginning, but rather ex principio, of the beginning; for He would not have created in, but of, matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:6
verses.text: When Wisdom, however, was referred to, it was quite right to say, in the beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:7
verses.text: For it was in Wisdom that He made all things at first, because by meditating and arranging His plans therein, He had in fact already done (the work of creation); and if He had even intended to create out of matter, He would yet have effected His creation when He previously meditated on it and arranged it in His Wisdom, since It was in fact the beginning of His ways:  this meditation and arrangement being the primal operation of Wisdom, opening as it does the way to the works by the act of meditation and thought.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:8
verses.text: This authority of Scripture I claim for myself even from this circumstance, that whilst it shows me the God who created, and the works He created, it does not in like manner reveal to me the source from which He created.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:9
verses.text: For since in every operation there are three principal things, He who makes, and that which is made, and that of which it is made, there must be three names mentioned in a correct narrative of the operation—the person of the maker the sort of thing which is made, and the material of which it is formed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:10
verses.text: If the material is not mentioned, while the work and the maker of the work are both mentioned, it is manifest that He made the work out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:11
verses.text: For if He had had anything to operate upon, it would have been mentioned as well as (the other two particulars).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:12
verses.text: In conclusion, I will apply the Gospel as a supplementary testimony to the Old Testament.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:13
verses.text: Now in this there is all the greater reason why there should be shown the material (if there were any) out of which God made all things, inasmuch as it is therein plainly revealed by whom He made all things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:14
verses.text: "In the beginning was the Word"—that is, the same beginning, of course, in which God made the heaven and the earth—"and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:15
verses.text: All things were made by Him, and without Him nothing was made".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 20:16
verses.text: Now, since we have here clearly told us who the Maker was, that is, God, and what He made, even all things, and through whom He made them, even His Word, would not the order of the narrative have required that the source out of which all things were made by God through the Word should likewise be declared, if they had been in fact made out of anything? What, therefore, did not exist, the Scripture was unable to mention; and by not mentioning it, it has given us a clear proof that there was no such thing: for if there had been, the Scripture would have mentioned it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 21:1
verses.text: A Retort of Heresy Answered.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 21:2
verses.text: That Scripture Should in So Many Words Tell Us that the World Was Made of Nothing is Superfluous.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 21:3
verses.text: But, you will say to me, if you determine that all things were made of nothing, on the ground that it is not told us that anything was made out of pre-existent Matter, take care that it be not contended on the opposite side, that on the same ground all things were made out of Matter, because it is not likewise expressly said that anything was made out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 21:4
verses.text: Some arguments may, of course, be thus retorted easily enough; but it does not follow that they are on that account fairly admissible, where there is a diversity in the cause.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 21:5
verses.text: For I maintain that, even if the Scripture has not expressly declared that all things were made out of nothing—just as it abstains (from saying that they were formed) out of Matter—there was no such pressing need for expressly indicating the creation of all things out of nothing, as there was of their creation out of Matter, if that had been their origin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 21:6
verses.text: Because, in the case of what is made out of nothing, the very fact of its not being indicated that it was made of any particular thing shows that it was made of nothing; and there is no danger of its being supposed that it was made of anything, when there is no indication at all of what it was made of.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 21:7
verses.text: In the case, however, of that which is made out of something, unless the very fact be plainly declared, that it was made out of something, there will be danger, until it is shown of what it was made, first of its appearing to be made of nothing, because it is not said of what it was made; and then, should it be of such a nature as to have the appearance of having certainly been made of something, there will be a similar risk of its seeming to have been made of a far different material from the proper one, so long as there is an absence of statement of what it was made of.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 21:8
verses.text: Then, if God had been unable to make all things of nothing, the Scripture could not possibly have added that He had made all things of nothing: (there could have been no room for such a statement,) but it must by all means have informed us that He had made all things out of Matter, since Matter must have been the source; because the one case was quite to be understood, if it were not actually stated, whereas the other case would be left in doubt unless it were stated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:1
verses.text: This Conclusion Confirmed by the Usage of Holy Scripture in Its History of the Creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:2
verses.text: Hermogenes in Danger of the Woe Pronounced Against Adding to Scripture.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:3
verses.text: And to such a degree has the Holy Ghost made this the rule of His Scripture, that whenever anything is made out of anything, He mentions both the thing that is made and the thing of which it is made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:4
verses.text: "Let the earth," says He, "bring forth grass, the herb yielding seed, and the fruit-tree yielding fruit after its kind, whose seed is in itself, after its kind.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:5
verses.text: And it was so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:6
verses.text: And the earth brought forth grass, and herb yielding seed after its kind, and the tree yielding fruit, whose seed was in itself, after its kind".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:7
verses.text: And again:  "And God said, Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creatures that have life, and fowl that may fly above the earth through the firmament of heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:8
verses.text: And it was so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:9
verses.text: And God created great whales, and every living creature that moveth, which the waters brought forth abundantly, after their kind".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:10
verses.text: Again afterwards: "And God said, Let the earth bring forth the living creature after his kind, cattle, and creeping thing, and beasts of the earth after their kind".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:11
verses.text: If therefore God, when producing other things out of things which had been already made, indicates them by the prophet, and tells us what He has produced from such and such a source (although we might ourselves suppose them to be derived from some source or other, short of nothing; since there had already been created certain things, from which they might easily seem to have been made); if the Holy Ghost took upon Himself so great a concern for our instruction, that we might know from what everything was produced, would He not in like manner have kept us well informed about both the heaven and the earth, by indicating to us what it was that He made them of, if their original consisted of any material substance, so that the more He seemed to have made them of nothing, the less in fact was there as yet made, from which He could appear to have made them?  Therefore, just as He shows us the original out of which He drew such things as were derived from a given source, so also with regard to those things of which He does not point out whence He produced them, He confirms (by that silence our assertion) that they were produced out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:12
verses.text: "In the beginning," then, "God made the heaven and the earth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:13
verses.text: I revere the fulness of His Scripture, in which He manifests to me both the Creator and the creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:14
verses.text: In the gospel, moreover, I discover a Minister and Witness of the Creator, even His Word.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:15
verses.text: But whether all things were made out of any underlying Matter, I have as yet failed anywhere to find.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:16
verses.text: Where such a statement is written, Hermogenes' shop must tell us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 22:17
verses.text: If it is nowhere written, then let it fear the woe which impends on all who add to or take away from the written word.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:1
verses.text: Hermogenes Pursued to Another Passage of Scripture.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:2
verses.text: The Absurdity of His Interpretation Exposed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:3
verses.text: But he draws an argument from the following words, where it is written:  "And the earth was without form, and void".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:4
verses.text: For he resolves the word earth into Matter, because that which is made out of it is the earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:5
verses.text: And to the word was he gives the same direction, as if it pointed to what had always existed unbegotten and unmade.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:6
verses.text: It was without form, moreover, and void, because he will have Matter to have existed shapeless and confused, and without the finish of a maker's hand.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:7
verses.text: Now these opinions of his I will refute singly; but first I wish to say to him, by way of general answer: We are of opinion that Matter is pointed at in these terms.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:8
verses.text: But yet does the Scripture intimate that, because Matter was in existence before all, anything of like condition was even formed out of it? Nothing of the kind.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:9
verses.text: Matter might have had existence, if it so pleased—or rather if Hermogenes so pleased.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:10
verses.text: It might, I say, have existed, and yet God might not have made anything out of it, either as it was unsuitable to Him to have required the aid of anything, or at least because He is not shown to have made anything out of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:11
verses.text: Its existence must therefore be without a cause, you will say.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:12
verses.text: Oh, no! certainly not without cause.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 23:13
verses.text: For even if the world were not made out of it, yet a heresy has been hatched there from; and a specially impudent one too, because it is not Matter which has produced the heresy, but the heresy has rather made Matter itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 24:1
verses.text: Earth Does Not Mean Matter as Hermogenes Would Have It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 24:2
verses.text: I now return to the several points by means of which he thought that Matter was signified.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 24:3
verses.text: And first I will inquire about the terms.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 24:4
verses.text: For we read only of one of them, Earth; the other, namely Matter, we do not meet with.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 24:5
