verses.text: I ask, then, since Matter is not mentioned in Scripture, how the term earth can be applied to it, which marks a substance of another kind? There is all the greater need why mention should also have been made of Matter, if this has acquired the further sense of Earth, in order that I may be sure that Earth is one and the same name as Matter, and so not claim the designation for merely one substance, as the proper name thereof, and by which it is better known; or else be unable (if I should feel the inclination), to apply it to some particular species of Matter, instead, indeed, of making it the common term of all Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 24:6
verses.text: For when a proper name does not exist for that thing to which a common term is ascribed, the less apparent is the object to which it may be ascribed, the more capable will it be of being applied to any other object whatever.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 24:7
verses.text: Therefore, even supposing that Hermogenes could show us the name Matter, he is bound to prove to us further, that the same object has the surname Earth, in order that he may claim for it both designations alike.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:1
verses.text: The Assumption that There are Two Earths Mentioned in the History of the Creation, Refuted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:2
verses.text: He accordingly maintains that there are two earths set before us in the passage in question: one, which God made in the beginning; the other being the Matter of which God made the world, and concerning which it is said, "And the earth was without form, and void".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:3
verses.text: Of course, if I were to ask, to which of the two earths the name earth is best suited, I shall be told that the earth which was made derived the appellation from that of which it was made, on the ground that it is more likely that the offspring should get its name from the original, than the original from the offspring.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:4
verses.text: This being the case, another question presents itself to us, whether it is right and proper that this earth which God made should have derived its name from that out of which He made it? For I find from Hermogenes and the rest of the Materialist heretics, that while the one earth was indeed "without form, and void," this one of ours obtained from God in an equal degree both form, and beauty, and symmetry; and therefore that the earth which was created was a different thing from that out of which it was created.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:5
verses.text: Now, having become a different thing, it could not possibly have shared with the other in its name, after it had declined from its condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:6
verses.text: If earth was the proper name of the (original) Matter, this world of ours, which is not Matter, because it has become another thing, is unfit to bear the name of earth, seeing that that name belongs to something else, and is a stranger to its nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:7
verses.text: But (you will tell me) Matter which has undergone creation, that is, our earth, had with its original a community of name no less than of kind.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:8
verses.text: By no means.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:9
verses.text: For although the pitcher is formed out of the clay, I shall no longer call it clay, but a pitcher; so likewise, although electrum is compounded of gold and silver, I shall yet not call it either gold or silver, but electrum.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:10
verses.text: When there is a departure from the nature of any thing, there is likewise a relinquishment of its name—with a propriety which is alike demanded by the designation and the condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:11
verses.text: How great a change indeed from the condition of that earth, which is Matter, has come over this earth of ours, is plain even from the fact that the latter has received this testimony to its goodness in Genesis, "And God saw that it was good;" while the former, according to Hermogenes, is regarded as the origin and cause of all evils.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:12
verses.text: Lastly, if the one is Earth because the other is, why also is the one not Matter as the other is? Indeed, by this rule both the heaven and all creatures ought to have had the names of Earth and Matter, since they all consist of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:13
verses.text: I have said enough touching the designation Earth, by which he will have it that Matter is understood.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:14
verses.text: This, as everybody knows, is the name of one of the elements; for so we are taught by nature first, and afterwards by Scripture, except it be that credence must be given to that Silenus who talked so confidently in the presence of king Midas of another world, according to the account of Theopompus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 25:15
verses.text: But the same author informs us that there are also several gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:1
verses.text: The Method Observed in the History of the Creation, in Reply to the Perverse Interpretation of Hermogenes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:2
verses.text: We, however, have but one God, and but one earth too, which in the beginning God made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:3
verses.text: The Scripture, which at its very outset proposes to run through the order thereof tells us as its first information that it was created; it next proceeds to set forth what sort of earth it was.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:4
verses.text: In like manner with respect to the heaven, it informs us first of its creation—"In the beginning God made the heaven:" it then goes on to introduce its arrangement; how that God both separated "the water which was below the firmament from that which was above the firmament," and called the firmament heaven,—the very thing He had created in the beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:5
verses.text: Similarly it (afterwards) treats of man:  "And God created man, in the image of God made He him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:6
verses.text: It next reveals how He made him: "And (the Lord) God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:7
verses.text: Now this is undoubtedly the correct and fitting mode for the narrative.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:8
verses.text: First comes a prefatory statement, then follow the details in full; first the subject is named, then it is described.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:9
verses.text: How absurd is the other view of the account, when even before he had premised any mention of his subject, i-e: Matter, without even giving us its name, he all on a sudden promulged its form and condition, describing to us its quality before mentioning its existence,—pointing out the figure of the thing formed, but concealing its name! But how much more credible is our opinion, which holds that Scripture has only subjoined the arrangement of the subject after it has first duly described its formation and mentioned its name!  Indeed, how full and complete is the meaning of these words: "In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth; but the earth was without form, and void,"—the very same earth, no doubt, which God made, and of which the Scripture had been speaking at that very moment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:10
verses.text: For that very "but" is inserted into the narrative like a clasp, (in its function) of a conjunctive particle, to connect the two sentences indissolubly together: "But the earth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:11
verses.text: This word carries back the mind to that earth of which mention had just been made, and binds the sense thereunto.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 26:12
verses.text: Take away this "but," and the tie is loosened; so much so that the passage, "But the earth was without form, and void," may then seem to have been meant for any other earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 27:1
verses.text: Some Hair-Splitting Use of Words in Which His Opponent Had Indulged.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 27:2
verses.text: But you next praise your eyebrows, and toss back your head, and beckon with your finger, in characteristic disdain, and say: There is the was, looking as if it pointed to an eternal existence,—making its subject, of course, unbegotten and unmade, and on that account worthy of being supposed to be Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 27:3
verses.text: Well now, for my own part, I shall resort to no affected protestation, but simply reply that "was" may be predicated of everything—even of a thing which has been created, which was born, which once was not, and which is not your Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 27:4
verses.text: For of everything which has being, from whatever source it has it, whether it has it by a beginning or without a beginning, the word "was" will be predicated from the very fact that it exists.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 27:5
verses.text: To whatever thing the first tense of the verb is applicable for definition, to the same will be suitable the later form of the verb, when it has to descend to relation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 27:6
verses.text: "Est" (it is) forms the essential part of a definition, "erat" (it was) of a relation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 27:7
verses.text: Such are the trifles and subtleties of heretics, who wrest and bring into question the simple meaning of the commonest words.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 27:8
verses.text: A grand question it is, to be sure, whether "the earth was," which was made! The real point of discussion is, whether "being without form, and void," is a state which is more suitable to that which was created, or to that of which it was created, so that the predicate (was) may appertain to the same thing to which the subject (that which was) also belongs.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:1
verses.text: A Curious Inconsistency in Hermogenes Exposed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:2
verses.text: Certain Expressions in The History of Creation Vindicated in The True Sense.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:3
verses.text: But we shall show not only that this condition agreed with this earth of ours, but that it did not agree with that other (insisted on by Hermogenes).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:4
verses.text: For, inasmuch as pure Matter was thus subsistent with God, without the interposition indeed of any element at all (because as yet there existed nothing but itself and God), it could not of course have been invisible.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:5
verses.text: Because, although Hermogenes contends that darkness was inherent in the substance of Matter, a position which we shall have to meet in its proper place, yet darkness is visible even to a human being (for the very fact that there is the darkness is an evident one), much more is it so to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:6
verses.text: If indeed it had been invisible, its quality would not have been by any means discoverable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:7
verses.text: How, then, did Hermogenes find out that that substance was "without form," and confused and disordered, which, as being invisible, was not palpable to his senses? If this mystery was revealed to him by God, he ought to give us his proof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:8
verses.text: I want to know also, whether (the substance in question) could have been described as "void".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:9
verses.text: That certainly is "void" which is imperfect.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:10
verses.text: Equally certain is it, that nothing can be imperfect but that which is made; it is imperfect when it is not fully made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:11
verses.text: Certainly, you admit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:12
verses.text: Matter, therefore, which was not made at all, could not have been imperfect; and what was not imperfect was not "void".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:13
verses.text: Having no beginning, because it was not made, it was also unsusceptible of any void-condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:14
verses.text: For this void-condition is an accident of beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:15
verses.text: The earth, on the contrary, which was made, was deservedly called "void".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 28:16
verses.text: For as soon as it was made, it had the condition of being imperfect, previous to its completion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:1
verses.text: The Gradual Development of Cosmical Order Out of Chaos in the Creation, Beautifully Stated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:2
verses.text: God, indeed, consummated all His works in a due order; at first He paled them out, as it were, in their unformed elements, and then He arranged them in their finished beauty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:3
verses.text: For He did not all at once inundate light with the splendour of the sun, nor all at once temper darkness with the moon's assuaging ray.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:4
verses.text: The heaven He did not all at once bedeck with constellations and stars, nor did He at once fill the seas with their teeming monsters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:5
verses.text: The earth itself He did not endow with its varied fruitfulness all at once; but at first He bestowed upon it being, and then He filled it, that it might not be made in vain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:6
verses.text: For thus says Isaiah: "He created it not in vain; He formed it to be inhabited".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:7
verses.text: Therefore after it was made, and while awaiting its perfect state, it was "without form, and void:" "void" indeed, from the very fact that it was without form (as being not yet perfect to the sight, and at the same time unfurnished as yet with its other qualities); and "without form," because it was still covered with waters, as if with the rampart of its fecundating moisture, by which is produced our flesh, in a form allied with its own.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:8
verses.text: For to this purport does David say: "The earth is the Lord's, and the fulness thereof; the world, and all that dwell therein:  He hath founded it upon the seas, and on the streams hath He established it".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:9
verses.text: It was when the waters were withdrawn into their hollow abysses that the dry land became conspicuous, which was hitherto covered with its watery envelope.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:10
verses.text: Then it forthwith becomes "visible," God saying, "Let the water be gathered together into one mass, and let the dry land appear".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:11
verses.text: "Appear," says He, not "be made".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:12
verses.text: It had been already made, only in its invisible condition it was then waiting to appear.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:13
verses.text: "Dry," because it was about to become such by its severance from the moisture, but yet "land".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:14
verses.text: "And God called the dry land Earth," not Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:15
verses.text: And so, when it afterwards attains its perfection, it ceases to be accounted void, when God declares, "Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb yielding seed after its kind, and according to its likeness, and the fruit-tree yielding fruit, whose seed is in itself, after its kind".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:16
verses.text: Again:  "Let the earth bring forth the living creature after his kind, cattle, and creeping things, and beasts of the earth, after their kind".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:17
verses.text: Thus the divine Scripture accomplished its full order.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:18
verses.text: For to that, which it had at first described as "without form (invisible) and void," it gave both visibility and completion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:19
verses.text: Now no other Matter was "without form (invisible) and void".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:20
verses.text: Henceforth, then, Matter will have to be visible and complete.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:21
verses.text: So that I must see Matter, since it has become visible.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:22
verses.text: I must likewise recognize it as a completed thing, so as to be able to gather from it the herb bearing seed, and the tree yielding fruit, and that living creatures, made out of it, may minister to my need.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:23
verses.text: Matter, however, is nowhere, but the Earth is here, confessed to my view.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:24
verses.text: I see it, I enjoy it, ever since it ceased to be "without form (invisible), and void".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:25
verses.text: Concerning it most certainly did Isaiah speak when he said, "Thus saith the Lord that created the heavens, He was the God that formed the earth, and made it".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:26
verses.text: The same earth for certain did He form, which He also made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:27
verses.text: Now how did He form it? Of course by saying, "Let the dry land appear".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:28
verses.text: Why does He command it to appear, if it were not previously invisible? His purpose was also, that He might thus prevent His having made it in vain, by rendering it visible, and so fit for use.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:29
verses.text: And thus, throughout, proofs arise to us that this earth which we inhabit is the very same which was both created and formed by God, and that none other was "Without form, and void," than that which had been created and formed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 29:30
verses.text: It therefore follows that the sentence, "Now the earth was without form, and void," applies to that same earth which God mentioned separately along with the heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 30:1
verses.text: Another Passage in the Sacred History of the Creation, Released from the Mishandling of Hermogenes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 30:2
verses.text: The following words will in like manner apparently corroborate the conjecture of Hermogenes, "And darkness was upon the face of the deep, and the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the water;" as if these blended substances, presented us with arguments for his massive pile of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 30:3
verses.text: Now, so discriminating an enumeration of certain and distinct elements (as we have in this passage), which severally designates "darkness," "the deep," "the Spirit of God," "the waters," forbids the inference that anything confused or (from such confusion) uncertain is meant.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 30:4
verses.text: Still more, when He ascribed to them their own places, "darkness on the face of the deep," "the Spirit upon the face of the waters," He repudiated all confusion in the substances; and by demonstrating their separate position, He demonstrated also their distinction.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 30:5
verses.text: Most absurd, indeed, would it be that Matter, which is introduced to our view as "without form," should have its "formless" condition maintained by so many words indicative of form, without any intimation of what that confused body is, which must of course be supposed to be unique, since it is without form.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 30:6
verses.text: For that which is without form is uniform; but even that which is without form, when it is blended together from various component parts, must necessarily have one outward appearance; and it has not any appearance, until it has the one appearance (which comes) from many parts combined.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 30:7
verses.text: Now Matter either had those specific parts within itself, from the words indicative of which it had to be understood—I mean "darkness," and "the deep," and "the Spirit," and "the waters"—or it had them not.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 30:8
verses.text: If it had them, how is it introduced as being "without form?" If it had them not, how does it become known?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:1
verses.text: A Further Vindication of the Scripture Narrative of the Creation, Against a Futile View of Hermogenes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:2
verses.text: But this circumstance, too, will be caught at, that Scripture meant to indicate of the heaven only, and this earth of yours, that God made it in the beginning, while nothing of the kind is said of the above-mentioned specific parts; and therefore that these, which are not described as having been made, appertain to unformed Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:3
verses.text: To this point also we must give an answer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:4
verses.text: Holy Scripture would be sufficiently explicit, if it had declared that the heaven and the earth, as the very highest works of creation, were made by God, possessing of course their own special appurtenances, which might be understood to be implied in these highest works themselves.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:5
verses.text: Now the appurtenances of the heaven and the earth, made then in the beginning, were the darkness and the deep, and the spirit, and the waters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:6
verses.text: For the depth and the darkness underlay the earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:7
verses.text: Since the deep was under the earth, and the darkness was over the deep, undoubtedly both the darkness and the deep were under the earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:8
verses.text: Below the heaven, too, lay the spirit and the waters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:9
verses.text: For since the waters were over the earth, which they covered, whilst the spirit was over the waters, both the spirit and the waters were alike over the earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:10
verses.text: Now that which is over the earth, is of course under the heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:11
verses.text: And even as the earth brooded over the deep and the darkness, so also did the heaven brood over the spirit and the waters, and embrace them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:12
verses.text: Nor, indeed, is there any novelty in mentioning only that which contains, as pertaining to the whole, and understanding that which is contained as included in it, in its character of a portion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:13
verses.text: Suppose now I should say the city built a theatre and a circus, but the stage was of such and such a kind, and the statues were on the canal, and the obelisk was reared above them all, would it follow that, because I did not distinctly state that these specific things were made by the city, they were therefore not made by it along with the circus and the theatre? Did I not, indeed, refrain from specially mentioning the formation of these particular things because they were implied in the things which I had already said were made, and might be understood to be inherent in the things in which they were contained? But this example may be an idle one as being derived from a human circumstance; I will take another, which has the authority of Scripture itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:14
verses.text: It says that "God made man of the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living soul".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:15
verses.text: Now, although it here mentions the nostrils, it does not say that they were made by God; so again it speaks of skin and bones, and flesh and eyes, and sweat and blood, in subsequent passages, and yet it never intimated that they had been created by God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:16
verses.text: What will Hermogenes have to answer? That the human limbs must belong to Matter, because they are not specially mentioned as objects of creation? Or are they included in the formation of man? In like manner, the deep and the darkness, and the spirit and the waters, were as members of the heaven and the earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:17
verses.text: For in the bodies the limbs were made, in the bodies the limbs too were mentioned.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:18
verses.text: No element but what is a member of that element in which it is contained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 31:19
verses.text: But all elements are contained in the heaven and the earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:1
verses.text: The Account of the Creation in Genesis a General One, Corroborated, However, by Many Other Passages of the Old Testament, Which Give Account of Specific Creations.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:2
verses.text: Further Cavillings Confuted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:3
verses.text: This is the answer I should give in defence of the Scripture before us, for seeming here to set forth the formation of the heaven and the earth, as if (they were) the sole bodies made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:4
verses.text: It could not but know that there were those who would at once in the bodies understand their several members also, and therefore it employed this concise mode of speech.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:5
verses.text: But, at the same time, it foresaw that there would be stupid and crafty men, who, after paltering with the virtual meaning, would require for the several members a word descriptive of their formation too.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:6
verses.text: It is therefore because of such persons, that Scripture in other passages teaches us of the creation of the individual parts.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:7
verses.text: You have Wisdom saying, "But before the depths was I brought forth," in order that you may believe that the depths were also "brought forth"—that is, created—just as we create sons also, though we "bring them forth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:8
verses.text: It matters not whether the depth was made or born, so that a beginning be accorded to it, which however would not be, if it were subjoined to matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:9
verses.text: Of darkness, indeed, the Lord Himself by Isaiah says, "I formed the light, and I created darkness".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:10
verses.text: Of the wind also Amos says, "He that strengtheneth the thunder, and createth the wind, and declareth His Christ unto men;" thus showing that that wind was created which was reckoned with the formation of the earth, which was wafted over the waters, balancing and refreshing and animating all things: not (as some suppose) meaning God Himself by the spirit, on the ground that "God is a Spirit," because the waters would not be able to bear up their Lord; but He speaks of that spirit of which the winds consist, as He says by Isaiah, "Because my spirit went forth from me, and I made every blast".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:11
verses.text: In like manner the same Wisdom says of the waters, "Also when He made the fountains strong, things which are under the sky, I was fashioning them along with Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:12
verses.text: Now, when we prove that these particular things were created by God, although they are only mentioned in Genesis, without any intimation of their having been made, we shall perhaps receive from the other side the reply, that these were made, it is true, but out of Matter, since the very statement of Moses, "And darkness was on the face of the deep, and the spirit of God moved on the face of the waters," refers to Matter, as indeed do all those other Scriptures here and there, which demonstrate that the separate parts were made out of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:13
verses.text: It must follow, then, that as earth consisted of earth, so also depth consisted of depth, and darkness of darkness, and the wind and waters of wind and waters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:14
verses.text: And, as we said above, Matter could not have been without form, since it had specific parts, which were formed out of it—although as separate things—unless, indeed, they were not separate, but were the very same with those out of which they came.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:15
verses.text: For it is really impossible that those specific things, which are set forth under the same names, should have been diverse; because in that case the operation of God might seem to be useless, if it made things which existed already; since that alone would be a creation, when things came into being, which had not been (previously) made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 32:16
verses.text: Therefore, to conclude, either Moses then pointed to Matter when he wrote the words: "And darkness was on the face of the deep, and the spirit of God moved on the face of the waters;" or else, inasmuch as these specific parts of creation are afterwards shown in other passages to have been made by God, they ought to have been with equal explicitness shown to have been made out of the Matter which, according to you, Moses had previously mentioned; or else, finally, if Moses pointed to those specific parts, and not to Matter, I want to know where Matter has been pointed out at all.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 33:1
verses.text: Statement of the True Doctrine Concerning Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 33:2
verses.text: Its Relation to God's Creation of the World.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 33:3
verses.text: But although Hermogenes finds it amongst his own colourable pretences (for it was not in his power to discover it in the Scriptures of God), it is enough for us, both that it is certain that all things were made by God, and that there is no certainty whatever that they were made out of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 33:4
verses.text: And even if Matter had previously existed, we must have believed that it had been really made by God, since we maintained (no less) when we held the rule of faith to be, that nothing except God was uncreated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 33:5
verses.text: Up to this point there is room for controversy, until Matter is brought to the test of the Scriptures, and fails to make good its case.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 33:6
verses.text: The conclusion of the whole is this: I find that there was nothing made, except out of nothing; because that which I find was made, I know did not once exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 33:7
verses.text: Whatever was made out of something, has its origin in something made: for instance, out of the ground was made the grass, and the fruit, and the cattle, and the form of man himself; so from the waters were produced the animals which swim and fly.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 33:8
verses.text: The original fabrics out of which such creatures were produced I may call their materials, but then even these were created by God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:1
verses.text: A Presumption that All Things Were Created by God Out of Nothing Afforded by the Ultimate Reduction of All Things to Nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:2
verses.text: Scriptures Proving This Reduction Vindicated from Hermogenes' Charge of Being Merely Figurative.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:3
verses.text: Besides, the belief that everything was made from nothing will be impressed upon us by that ultimate dispensation of God which will bring back all things to nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:4
verses.text: For "the very heaven shall be rolled together as a scroll;" nay, it shall come to nothing along with the earth itself, with which it was made in the beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:5
verses.text: "Heaven and earth shall pass away," says He.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:6
verses.text: "The first heaven and the first earth passed away," "and there was found no place for them," because, of course, that which comes to an end loses locality.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:7
verses.text: In like manner David says, "The heavens, the works of Thine hands, shall themselves perish.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:8
verses.text: For even as a vesture shall He change them, and they shall be changed".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:9
verses.text: Now to be changed is to fall from that primitive state which they lose whilst undergoing the change.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:10
verses.text: "And the stars too shall fall from heaven, even as a fig-tree casteth her green figs when she is shaken of a mighty wind".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:11
verses.text: "The mountains shall melt like wax at the presence of the Lord;" that is, "when He riseth to shake terribly the earth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:12
verses.text: "But I will dry up the pools;" and "they shall seek water, and they shall find none".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:13
verses.text: Even "the sea shall be no more".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:14
verses.text: Now if any person should go so far as to suppose that all these passages ought to be spiritually interpreted, he will yet be unable to deprive them of the true accomplishment of those issues which must come to pass just as they have been written.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:15
verses.text: For all figures of speech necessarily arise out of real things, not out of chimerical ones; because nothing is capable of imparting anything of its own for a similitude, except it actually be that very thing which it imparts in the similitude.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:16
verses.text: I return therefore to the principle which defines that all things which have come from nothing shall return at last to nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:17
verses.text: For God would not have made any perishable thing out of what was eternal, that is to say, out of Matter; neither out of greater things would He have created inferior ones, to whose character it would be more agreeable to produce greater things out of inferior ones,—in other words, what is eternal out of what is perishable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 34:18
verses.text: This is the promise He makes even to our flesh, and it has been His will to deposit within us this pledge of His own virtue and power, in order that we may believe that He has actually awakened the universe out of nothing, as if it had been steeped in death, in the sense, of course, of its previous non-existence for the purpose of its coming into existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 35:1
verses.text: Contradictory Propositions Advanced by Hermogenes Respecting Matter and Its Qualities.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 35:2
verses.text: As regards all other points touching Matter, although there is no necessity why we should treat of them (for our first point was the manifest proof of its existence), we must for all that pursue our discussion just as if it did exist, in order that its non-existence may be the more apparent, when these other points concerning it prove inconsistent with each other, and in order at the same time that Hermogenes may acknowledge his own contradictory positions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 35:3
verses.text: Matter, says he, at first sight seems to us to be incorporeal; but when examined by the light of right reason, it is found to be neither corporeal nor incorporeal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 35:4
verses.text: What is this right reason of yours, which declares nothing right, that is, nothing certain? For, if I mistake not, everything must of necessity be either corporeal or incorporeal (although I may for the moment allow that there is a certain incorporeality in even substantial things, although their very substance is the body of particular things); at all events, after the corporeal and the incorporeal there is no third state.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 35:5
verses.text: But if it be contended that there is a third state discovered by this right reason of Hermogenes, which makes Matter neither corporeal nor incorporeal, (I ask,) Where is it? what sort of thing is it? what is it called? what is its description? what is it understood to be? This only has his reason declared, that Matter is neither corporeal nor incorporeal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:1
verses.text: Other Absurd Theories Respecting Matter and Its Incidents Exposed in an Ironical Strain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:2
verses.text: Motion in Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:3
verses.text: Hermogenes' Conceits Respecting It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:4
verses.text: But see what a contradiction he next advances (or perhaps some other reason occurs to him), when he declares that Matter partly corporeal and partly incorporeal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:5
verses.text: Then must Matter be considered (to embrace) both conditions, in order that it may not have either? For it will be corporeal, and incorporeal in spite of the declaration of that antithesis, which is plainly above giving any reason for its opinion, just as that "other reason" also was.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:6
verses.text: Now, by the corporeal part of Matter, he means that of which bodies are created; but by the incorporeal part of Matter, he means its uncreated motion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:7
verses.text: If, says he, Matter were simply a body, there would appear to be in it nothing incorporeal, that is, (no) motion; if, on the other hand, it had been wholly incorporeal no body could be formed out of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:8
verses.text: What a peculiarly right reason have we here! Only if you make your sketches as right as you make your reason, Hermogenes, no painter would be more stupid than yourself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:9
verses.text: For who is going to allow you to reckon motion as a moiety of Matter, seeing that it is not a substantial thing, because it is not corporeal, but an accident (if indeed it be even that) of a substance and a body?  Just as action is, and impulsion, just as a slip is, or a fall, so is motion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:10
verses.text: When anything moves even of itself, its motion is the result of impulse; but certainly it is no part of its substance in your sense, when you make motion the incorporeal part of matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:11
verses.text: All things, indeed, have motion—either of themselves as animals, or of others as inanimate things; but yet we should not say that either a man or a stone was both corporeal and incorporeal because they had both a body and motion: we should say rather that all things have one form of simple corporeality, which is the essential quality of substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:12
verses.text: If any incorporeal incidents accrue to them, as actions, or passions, or functions, or desires, we do not reckon these parts as of the things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:13
verses.text: How then does he contrive to assign an integral portion of Matter to motion, which does not pertain to substance, but to a certain condition of substance? Is not this incontrovertible? Suppose you had taken it into your head to represent matter as immoveable, would then the immobility seem to you to be a moiety of its form? Certainly not.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:14
verses.text: Neither, in like manner, could motion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 36:15
verses.text: But I shall be at liberty to speak of motion elsewhere.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:1
verses.text: Ironical Dilemmas Respecting Matter, and Sundry Moral Qualities Fancifully Attributed to It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:2
verses.text: I see now that you are coming back again to that reason, which has been in the habit of declaring to you nothing in the way of certainty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:3
verses.text: For just as you introduce to our notice Matter as being neither corporeal nor incorporeal, so you allege of it that it is neither good nor evil; and you say, whilst arguing further on it in the same strain: "If it were good, seeing that it had ever been so, it would not require the arrangement of itself by God; if it were naturally evil, it would not have admitted of a change for the better, nor would God have ever applied to such a nature any attempt at arrangement of it, for His labour would have been in vain".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:4
verses.text: Such are your words, which it would have been well if you had remembered in other passages also, so as to have avoided any contradiction of them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:5
verses.text: As, however, we have already treated to some extent of this ambiguity of good and evil touching Matter, I will now reply to the only proposition and argument of yours which we have before us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:6
verses.text: I shall not stop to repeat my opinion, that it was your bounden duty to have said for certain that Matter was either good or bad, or in some third condition; but (I must observe) that you have not here even kept to the statement which you chose to make before.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:7
verses.text: Indeed, you retract what you declared—that Matter is neither good nor evil; because you imply that it is evil when you say, "If it were good, it would not require to be set in order by God;" so again, when you add, "If it were naturally evil, it would not admit of any change for the better," you seem to intimate that it is good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:8
verses.text: And so you attribute to it a close relation to good and evil, although you declared it neither good nor evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:9
verses.text: With a view, however, to refute the argument whereby you thought you were going to clinch your proposition, I here contend: If Matter had always been good, why should it not have still wanted a change for the better? Does that which is good never desire, never wish, never feel able to advance, so as to change its good for a better? And in like manner, if Matter had been by nature evil, why might it not have been changed by God as the more powerful Being, as able to convert the nature of stones into children of Abraham? Surely by such means you not only compare the Lord with Matter, but you even put Him below it, since you affirm that the nature of Matter could not possibly be brought under control by Him, and trained to something better.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 37:10
verses.text: But although you are here disinclined to allow that Matter is by nature evil, yet in another passage you will deny having made such an admission.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:1
verses.text: Other Speculations of Hermogenes, About Matter and Some of Its Adjuncts, Shown to Be Absurd.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:2
verses.text: For Instance, Its Alleged Infinity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:3
verses.text: My observations touching the site of Matter, as also concerning its mode have one and the same object in view—to meet and refute your perverse positions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:4
verses.text: You put Matter below God, and thus, of course, you assign a place to it below God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:5
verses.text: Therefore Matter is local.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:6
verses.text: Now, if it is local, it is within locality; if within locality, it is bounded by the place within which it is; if it is bounded, it has an outline, which (painter as you are in your special vocation) you know is the boundary to every object susceptible of outline.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:7
verses.text: Matter, therefore, cannot be infinite, which, since it is in space, is bounded by space; and being thus determinable by space, it is susceptible of an outline.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:8
verses.text: You, however, make it infinite, when you say: "It is on this account infinite, because it is always existent".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:9
verses.text: And if any of your disciples should choose to meet us by declaring your meaning to be that Matter is infinite in time, not in its corporeal mass, still what follows will show that (you mean) corporeal infinity to be an attribute of Matter, that it is in respect of bulk immense and uncircumscribed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:10
verses.text: "Wherefore," say you, "it is not fabricated as a whole, but in its parts".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:11
verses.text: In bulk, therefore, is it infinite, not in time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:12
verses.text: And you contradict yourself when you make Matter infinite in bulk, and at the same time ascribe place to it, including it within space and local outline.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:13
verses.text: But yet at the same time I cannot tell why God should not have entirely formed it, unless it be because He was either impotent or envious.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:14
verses.text: I want therefore to know the moiety of that which was not wholly formed (by God), in order that I may understand what kind of thing the entirety was.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 38:15
verses.text: It was only right that God should have made it known as a model of antiquity, to set off the glory of His work.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 39:1
verses.text: These Latter Speculations Shown to Be Contradictory to the First Principles Respecting Matter, Formerly Laid Down by Hermogenes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 39:2
verses.text: Well, now, since it seems to you to be the correcter thing, let Matter be circumscribed by means of changes and displacements; let it also be capable of comprehension, since (as you say) it is used as material by God, on the ground of its being convertible, mutable, and separable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 39:3
verses.text: For its changes, you say, show it to be inseparable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 39:4
verses.text: And here you have swerved from your own lines which you prescribed respecting the person of God when you laid down the rule that God made it not out of His own self, because it was not possible for Him to become divided seeing that He is eternal and abiding for ever, and therefore unchangeable and indivisible.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 39:5
verses.text: Since Matter too is estimated by the same eternity, having neither beginning nor end, it will be unsusceptible of division, of change, for the same reason that God also is.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 39:6
verses.text: Since it is associated with Him in the joint possession of eternity, it must needs share with Him also the powers, the laws, and the conditions of eternity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 39:7
verses.text: In like manner, when you say, "All things simultaneously throughout the universe possess portions of it, that so the whole may be ascertained from its parts," you of course mean to indicate those parts which were produced out of it, and which are now visible to us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 39:8
verses.text: How then is this possession (of Matter) by all things throughout the universe effected—that is, of course, from the very beginning—when the things which are now visible to us are different in their condition from what they were in the beginning?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 40:1
verses.text: Shapeless Matter an Incongruous Origin for God's Beautiful Cosmos.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 40:2
verses.text: Hermogenes Does Not Mend His Argument by Supposing that Only a Portion of Matter Was Used in the Creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 40:3
verses.text: You say that Matter was reformed for the better—from a worse condition, of course; and thus you would make the better a copy of the worse.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 40:4
verses.text: Everything was in confusion, but now it is reduced to order; and would you also say, that out of order, disorder is produced? No one thing is the exact mirror of another thing; that is to say, it is not its co-equal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 40:5
verses.text: Nobody ever found himself in a barber's looking-glass look like an ass instead of a man; unless it be he who supposes that unformed and shapeless Matter answers to Matter which is now arranged and beautified in the fabric of the world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 40:6
verses.text: What is there now that is without form in the world, what was there once that was formed in Matter, that the world is the mirror of Matter? Since the world is known among the Greeks by a term denoting ornament, how can it present the image of unadorned Matter, in such a way that you can say the whole is known by its parts? To that whole will certainly belong even the portion which has not yet become formed; and you have already declared that the whole of Matter was not used as material in the creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 40:7
verses.text: It follows, then, that this rude, and confused, and unarranged portion cannot be recognized in the polished, and distinct and well-arranged parts of creation, which indeed can hardly with propriety be called parts of Matter, since they have quitted its condition, by being separated from it in the transformation they have undergone.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:1
verses.text: Sundry Quotations from Hermogenes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:2
verses.text: Now Uncertain and Vague are His Speculations Respecting Motion in Matter, and the Material Qualities of Good and Evil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:3
verses.text: I come back to the point of motion, that I may show how slippery you are at every step.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:4
verses.text: Motion in Matter was disordered, and confused, and turbulent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:5
verses.text: This is why you apply to it the comparison of a boiler of hot water surging over.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:6
verses.text: Now how is it, that in another passage another sort of motion is affirmed by you?  For when you want to represent Matter as neither good nor evil, you say: "Matter, which is the substratum (of creation) possessing as it does motion in an equable impulse, tends in no very great degree either to good or to evil".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:7
verses.text: Now if it had this equable impulse, it could not be turbulent, nor be like the boiling water of the caldron; it would rather be even and regular, oscillating indeed of its own accord between good and evil, but yet not prone or tending to either side.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:8
verses.text: It would swing, as the phrase is, in a just and exact balance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:9
verses.text: Now this is not unrest; this is not turbulence or inconstancy; but rather the regularity, and evenness, and exactitude of a motion, inclining to neither side.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:10
verses.text: If it oscillated this way and that way, and inclined rather to one particular side, it would plainly in that case merit the reproach of unevenness, and inequality, and turbulence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:11
verses.text: Moreover, although the motion of Matter was not prone either to good or to evil, it would still, of course, oscillate between good and evil; so that from this circumstance too it is obvious that Matter is contained within certain limits, because its motion, while prone to neither good nor evil, since it had no natural bent either way, oscillated from either between both, and therefore was contained within the limits of the two.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:12
verses.text: But you, in fact, place both good and evil in a local habitation, when you assert that motion in Matter inclined to neither of them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:13
verses.text: For Matter which was local, when inclining neither hither nor thither, inclined not to the places in which good and evil were.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:14
verses.text: But when you assign locality to good and evil, you make them corporeal by making them local, since those things which have local space must needs first have bodily substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:15
verses.text: In fact, incorporeal things could not have any locality of their own except in a body, when they have access to a body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:16
verses.text: But when Matter inclined not to good and evil, it was as corporeal or local essences that it did not incline to them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:17
verses.text: You err, therefore, when you will have it that good and evil are substances.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 41:18
verses.text: For you make substances of the things to which you assign locality; but you assign locality when you keep motion in Matter poised equally distant from both sides.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:1
verses.text: Further Exposure of Inconsistencies in the Opinions of Hermogenes Respecting the Divine Qualities of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:2
verses.text: You have thrown out all your views loosely and at random, in order that it might not be apparent, by too close a proximity, how contrary they are to one another.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:3
verses.text: I, however, mean to gather them together and compare them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:4
verses.text: You allege that motion in Matter is without regularity, and you go on to say that Matter aims at a shapeless condition, and then, in another passage, that it desires to be set in order by God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:5
verses.text: Does that, then, which affects to be without form, want to be put into shape? Or does that which wants to be put into shape, affect to be without form? You are unwilling that God should seem to be equal to Matter; and then again you say that it has a common condition with God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:6
verses.text: "For it is impossible," you say, "if it has nothing in common with God, that it can be set in order by Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:7
verses.text: But if it had anything in common with God, it did not want to be set in order, being, forsooth, a part of the Deity through a community of condition; or else even God was susceptible of being set in order by Matter, by His having Himself something in common with it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:8
verses.text: And now you herein subject God to necessity, since there was in Matter something on account of which He gave it form.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:9
verses.text: You make it, however, a common attribute of both of them, that they set themselves in motion by themselves, and that they are ever in motion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:10
verses.text: What less do you ascribe to Matter than to God? There will be found all through a fellowship of divinity in this freedom and perpetuity of motion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:11
verses.text: Only in God motion is regular, in Matter irregular.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:12
verses.text: In both, however, there is equally the attribute of Deity—both alike having free and eternal motion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 42:13
verses.text: At the same time, you assign more to Matter, to which belonged the privilege of thus moving itself in a way not allowed to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:1
verses.text: Other Discrepancies Exposed and Refuted Respecting the Evil in Matter Being Changed to Good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:2
verses.text: On the subject of motion I would make this further remark.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:3
verses.text: Following the simile of the boiling caldron, you say that motion in Matter, before it was regulated, was confused, restless, incomprehensible by reason of excess in the commotion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:4
verses.text: Then again you go on to say, "But it waited for the regulation of God, and kept its irregular motion incomprehensible, owing to the tardiness of its irregular motion".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:5
verses.text: Just before you ascribe commotion, here tardiness, to motion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:6
verses.text: Now observe how many slips you make respecting the nature of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:7
verses.text: In a former passage you say, "If Matter were naturally evil, it would not have admitted of a change for the better; nor would God have ever applied to it any attempt at arrangement, for His labour would have been in vain".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:8
verses.text: You therefore concluded your two opinions, that Matter was not by nature evil, and that its nature was incapable of being changed by God; and then, forgetting them, you afterwards drew this inference: "But when it received adjustment from God, and was reduced to order, it relinquished its nature".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 43:9
verses.text: Now, inasmuch as it was transformed to good, it was of course transformed from evil; and if by God's setting it in order it relinquished the nature of evil, it follows that its nature came to an end; now its nature was evil before the adjustment, but after the transformation it might have relinquished that nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:1
verses.text: Curious Views Respecting God's Method of Working with Matter Exposed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:2
verses.text: Discrepancies in the Heretic's Opinion About God's Local Relation to Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:3
verses.text: But it remains that I should show also how you make God work.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:4
verses.text: You are plainly enough at variance with the philosophers; but neither are you in accord with the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:5
verses.text: The Stoics maintain that God pervaded Matter, just as honey the honeycomb.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:6
verses.text: You, however, affirm that it is not by pervading Matter that God makes the world, but simply by appearing, and approaching it, just as beauty affects a thing by simply appearing, and a loadstone by approaching it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:7
verses.text: Now what similarity is there in God forming the world, and beauty wounding a soul, or a magnet attracting iron? For even if God appeared to Matter, He yet did not wound it, as beauty does the soul; if, again, He approached it, He yet did not cohere to it, as the magnet does to the iron.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:8
verses.text: Suppose, however, that your examples are suitable ones.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:9
verses.text: Then, of course, it was by appearing and approaching to Matter that God made the world, and He made it when He appeared and when He approached to it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:10
verses.text: Therefore, since He had not made it before then, He had neither appeared nor approached to it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 44:11
verses.text: Now, by whom can it be believed that God had not appeared to Matter—of the same nature as it even was owing to its eternity? Or that He had been at a distance from it—even He whom we believe to be existent everywhere, and everywhere apparent; whose praises all things chant, even inanimate things and things incorporeal, according to (the prophet) Daniel? How immense the place, where God kept Himself so far aloof from Matter as to have neither appeared nor approached to it before the creation of the world! I suppose He journeyed to it from a long distance, as soon as He wished to appear and approach to it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:1
verses.text: Conclusion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:2
verses.text: Contrast Between the Statements of Hermogenes and the Testimony of Holy Scripture Respecting the Creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:3
verses.text: Creation Out of Nothing, Not Out of Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:4
verses.text: But it is not thus that the prophets and the apostles have told us that the world was made by God merely appearing and approaching Matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:5
verses.text: They did not even mention any Matter, but (said) that Wisdom was first set up, the beginning of His ways, for His works.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:6
verses.text: Then that the Word was produced, "through whom all things were made, and without whom nothing was made".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:7
verses.text: Indeed, "by the Word of the Lord were the heavens made, and all their hosts by the breath of His mouth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:8
verses.text: He is the Lord's right hand, indeed His two hands, by which He worked and constructed the universe.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:9
verses.text: "For," says He, "the heavens are the works of Thine hands," wherewith "He hath meted out the heaven, and the earth with a span".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:10
verses.text: Do not be willing so to cover God with flattery, as to contend that He produced by His mere appearance and simple approach so many vast substances, instead of rather forming them by His own energies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:11
verses.text: For this is proved by Jeremiah when he says, "God hath made the earth by His power, He hath established the world by His wisdom, and hath stretched out the heaven by His understanding".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:12
verses.text: These are the energies by the stress of which He made this universe.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:13
verses.text: His glory is greater if He laboured.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:14
verses.text: At length on the seventh day He rested from His works.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:15
verses.text: Both one and the other were after His manner.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:16
verses.text: If, on the contrary, He made this world simply by appearing and approaching it, did He, on the completion of His work, cease to appear and approach it any more.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:17
verses.text: Nay rather, God began to appear more conspicuously and to be everywhere accessible from the time when the world was made.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:18
verses.text: You see, therefore, how all things consist by the operation of that God who "made the earth by His power, who established the world by His wisdom, and stretched out the heaven by His understanding;" not appearing merely, nor approaching, but applying the almighty efforts of His mind, His wisdom, His power, His understanding, His word, His Spirit, His might.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:19
verses.text: Now these things were not necessary to Him, if He had been perfect by simply appearing and approaching.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:20
verses.text: They are, however, His "invisible things," which, according to the apostle, "are from the creation of the world clearly seen by the things that are made;" they are no parts of a nondescript Matter, but they are the sensible evidences of Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:21
verses.text: "For who hath known the mind of the Lord," of which (the apostle) exclaims: "O the depth of the riches both of His wisdom and knowledge! how unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out!" Now what clearer truth do these words indicate, than that all things were made out of nothing? They are incapable of being found out or investigated, except by God alone.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:22
verses.text: Otherwise, if they were traceable or discoverable in Matter, they would be capable of investigation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:23
verses.text: Therefore, in as far as it has become evident that Matter had no prior existence (even from this circumstance, that it is impossible for it to have had such an existence as is assigned to it), in so far is it proved that all things were made by God out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Hermogenes 45:24
verses.text: It must be admitted, however, that Hermogenes, by describing for Matter a condition like his own—irregular, confused, turbulent, of a doubtful and precipate and fervid impulse—has displayed a specimen of his own art, and painted his own portrait.
